My university experience with latex and markdown

I’ve been writing in LaTeX since my undergraduate years, and the things I learned from school about that is never enough.

Wanna type your own ideas on a computer? You’ve got many choices for the softwares, like the classical choice, Microsoft Word, which goes so graphical that even a nerd can perform 80% of its functionality. Personally I prefer Markdown, a simple programming language but with considerable power. In my sophomore year I’m a dickhead, only received a lecture on C programming for one semister and never have enough concentration to dive deeper, but I can write markdown.

Bad news. You cannot write LaTeX as easily as you write Markdown. Hey, listen, since TeX is developed far far ahead of time, a.k.a. in the Unix time, you cannot expect it to behave very much like the recent programming language. For python you have jupyter notebook. Code blocks. Direct output. No nasty settings. Good enough. The first time I know pip is not desiged to run inside the python terminal, I was shocked, since it feels so natural to just type pip install in jupyter notebook. In latex you often will have to worry about the indent at the start of each section. It’s writer’s responsibility to decide the final appearance of your draft. LaTeX assumes you to be an experienced programmer, while Jupyter Notebook assumes you a fool, only able to understand the basics.
